sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying inductor
message_1: A current of 2 A flows through a circular wire of radius 10 cm. Find the magnetic field at a point located 15 cm away from the center of the wire on the axis passing through it.
message_2:
To find the magnetic field at a point located on the axis passing through the center of the circular wire, we can use the formula for the magnetic field due to a circular loop of current:

B = (μ₀ * I * R²) / (2 * (R² + x²)^(3/2))

where:
B is the magnetic field
μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A)
I is the current (2 A)
R is the radius of the circular wire (0.1 m)
x is the distance from the center of the wire to the point where we want to find the magnetic field (0.15 m)

Plugging in the values, we get:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 2 A * (0.1 m)²) / (2 * ((0.1 m)² + (0.15 m)²)^(3/2))

B = (8π × 10^(-7) Tm * 0.01 m²) / (2 * (0.01 m² + 0.0225 m²)^(3/2))

B = (8π × 10^(-7) Tm * 0.01 m²) / (2 * (0.0325 m²)^(3/2))

B = (8π × 10^(-7) Tm * 0.01 m²) / (2 * 0.0325 m³)

B ≈ 1.22 × 10^(-5) T

So, the magnetic field at a point located 15 cm away from the center of the wire on the axis passing through it is approximately 1.22 × 10^(-5) T (Tesla).
